author: aarnette

description.text: Just in time for Valentine's Day! Follow along with this quick tutorial to create your own custom heart shaped box in Tinkercad! Watch the video for a overview of the design process https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Jh7wlbxoU_o. To design your own heart box, follow the steps below. Happy printing!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%

Instructions Watch the video for a overview of the design process. To follow along, follow the steps below. Happy printing! Step 1 Drag a Heart shape (found in the Symbols menu) onto the workplane. This will be the base of your heart box. We’ll call this the Base Heart. Step 2 Resize the Base Heart to your desired box size (we kept it pretty small, roughly 50 mm x 50 mm x 8 mm) Step 3 Use Edit -> Duplicate (or CTRL + D on your keyboard) to make a copy of your Base Heart. Step 4 Resize the duplicate box, this is what we will use to hollow out the box, we will call this shape the Heart Cutout. Tip: Hold SHIFT + AlLT on your keyboard when resizing to scale uniformly about the center of the object. Step 5 Select the Heart Cutout and change it to a Hole. Step 6 Create another duplicate of your Base Heart. This will serve as the Box Lid. Step 7 Drag the Box Lid upward and flatten it to roughly 5 mm. Step 8 Create a duplicate of the Heart Cutout and drag it upward. This part will be the Lid Bottom, the underside of the lid to keep it in place. Select a Color to turn it back into a solid part. Step 9 Resize the Lid Bottom (using SHIFT + ALT) so that it will fit within the Heart Cutout when printed. Flatten it to roughly 3 mm. Step 10 Drag the Lid Bottom upward so that it touches the Box Lid. Step 11 Group the Box Lid and Lid Bottom. Tip: hold SHIFT to select multiple objects for grouping Step 12 Group the Base Heart and Heart Cutout. Step 13 OPTIONAL: Drag out letters or other shapes onto the top of the lid to create a design. We used letters and turned them into Holes for easier printing. Step 14 Select the Lid part and navigate to Design -> Download for 3D Printing. Make sure to check the box labeled Download the Selected Shapes. Repeat for the Base Step 15 Import both STL files into MakerBot Desktop and lay them out for printing (we printed ours with the Lid facing downward and the Box facing upward). We selected Standard Settings and printed this on our MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation).

This part is designed to be made out of metal,
I first made it out of PLA to make sure it fit then had our machine shop make it out of aluminum.
The PLA one could be used as a template to make one without a machine shop.
It has been tested and ties both heater blocks together so they can not move when loosening a nozzle.
If it will not go on, it might be because your heater blocks are not aligned with each other, I also thought this might be a good tool to help align the heater blocks.
Feedback would be greatly appreciated.
The part is mounted with 2 4x6 mm socket head cap screws.
It is not designed to left on, you install it while removing a nozzle, then after you but the nozzle back on you remove it.
I did some small adjustments to the bow for this crossbow. The rubber band did not stay on, so I added some small slits in the end of the bow to hold the rubber band in place.

This is a simple, printable mounting system for FSR auto leveling (worse sensitive resistors). I've used these on Rostock Max, Kossel 250, Mini Kossel delta printers and also in a Taz 4 Cartesian printer. I highly recommend buying the FSR Kit from UltiBots - it comes with the JohnSL interface board, the wiring harnesses with preassembled connectors. They work perfectly with this mount.
UPDATE: I've added a second version that is designed for the Kossel 250 or similar printers. There are 2 mount parts, one is for a threaded insert, the other is plastic and can be threaded directly. This extra hole is for an M3 cap screw that fixes the Holddown part as shown in the attached photo.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm layers, 4 perimeters

Infill:

50%

Notes: I print these in PLA but make sure your heated bed has insulation under it if you do. ABS makes good parts too.

Print 3 holders, 3 plungers and 1 of the JohnSL brackets. The TAZ bracket holds the board vertically, the other holds it flat - which is more suitable for delta printers like the Rostock Max. It is critical that the plunger slides free - but without slop - in the mount. The plunger was designed with 3 points of contacts to make them easy to fit. First, clean out the pockets in the mounts to make sure they are smooth. Test the plunger. If it is too tight, lightly sand the surface of the 3 lobes with 400 or 600 grit paper and water. Rinse thoroughly so you don't introduce grit into the mechanism and test the fit often (after rinsing). Once the fit is perfect, keep the mount/plunger pair together. I lubricate the plunger with a little Vaseline or white lithium grease - VERY little! Printed mounts with FSRs inserted. Note that one of the silicon pads in the UltiBots kit goes on top of the FSR before the plunger. Mounts attached to the Rostock Max base. You can also attach them to aluminum 15x15 or 20x20 extrusions. The plunger is screwed to the bottom of the snowflake insulator on the Rostock. This is the little holder for the JohnSL board Holddown for the Kossel 250 version.

Thanks for the reply.
on the triangle, nope, common misconseption. instinct tells you that, but the largest equilateral intriangle solution is always one point in a corner, sides 15deg. angle from the side of a square. (oragami with my eldest).
so on any greatest equalateral intriangel on a given square is Vert A,B,C 60 Deg. where A,B,C,D 90 Deg. Point A0,0 on both.

title: 40mm J-Head v6 snap on fan mount

description.text:
So after searching for quite a while for a 40mm fan mount for my hotend, the closest thing I found was a design that sat in the fins.
1 metled extruder later, I've designed my own.
This is designed to fit around a chinese clone of the v6, not the fat ones, the thin ones (22mm diameter heat sink) if someone needs one for the real deal (25mm heat sink) it won't be hard for me to edit it.
The screw holes on this design may or may not work, they aren't fan size holes, as I made them 3mm diameter, I used zip ties to hold my fan to it, if someone needs one that can use screws let me know.
As you can see from the pictures, I'm using half of a fan stack from a 1u rack mount server, the overkill comes from having 2 extruders melt from poor cooling. Since I've used such a huge fan and it works, any smaller fan (basically every other fan on the market) should work just fine as well.
This was designed in solidworks, if you need the file converted to something for your cad program, let me know.

title: Valatines Day Heart With Name Plaque

description.text:
Designed by Omutant2 for Bilby 3D to celebrate Valantines day and teach people about adding 3D text to existing stl files HOW TO ADD TEXT?CREATE TEXT
This model was designed to add you and your loved ones name on the plaques. WE chose to print them in white to stand out, and glue them on. This way you can also curve the text on the plaque. You may also Imbed the text into the one stl file using one of the two methods here. Step 1: Open the heart file in SKETCHUP using the IMPORT function (see image 2). Step 2 : Create the text and check it is the correct size using the TOOLS-3D Text feature. We used 7mm height and 3mm extrusion depth. (see image 2 and 3) Step 3 either place text in model now, or save text as its own stl. See image 4 Step 4 print. You can also imbed text in your printer slicer at this point. We changed colour at the end of base to red from BIlby 3D copper (https://www.bilby3d.com.au/DispProd.asp?ProdID=PLA175CopperSML) to flashforge red (https://www.bilby3d.com.au/DispProd.asp?ProdID=FFpla175red06) We glued on names with Epoxie glue
Enjoy :) About the designer:
Hi there, I'm omutant, the creator of this 3D model, made in blender with about 5 hours of playing around. I am a freelance artist, currently working on 3 video game projects If you like my art, and want me to draw or 3D model something for you, I can do a commission for you. Just send me a note here http://omutant2.deviantart.com/

Hi there, I'm omutant, the creator of this 3D model, made in blender with about 5 hours of playing around. I started out with a cylinder, modeling the basic shape of the heart and base from a perfect front view, then moved on to the side view, and finished it off by refining it as a low poly shape from a 3Q perspective view.
once I was happy with the basic shape of the object, I applied a multiresolution modifier to give the model a smoother surface, and started refining further, making the smaller details like the name platforms and flatter surfaces, such as the mid section of the heart.
After the heart was complete, I moved on to doing the rope, starting off with a cylinder again, adding an array modifier, and a curve modifier, to make the shape follow a Bezier path, finishing off with a basic transformation of the base shape, to give the twisty effect without increasing the polycount too much..

I was tired of the little rubber feet that come with the terrariums to keep the heat mat from getting pinched falling off.  I made these for all of my cages and used double sided tape / hot glue to attach them.

One more variation on an Owen design. This part replaces wooden hot end component labeled 8A. I have several variations here:
[UPH-01-001] Basic printable replacement for wood part 8A.
[UPH-01-002] Same part with integrated Bowden clamp.(shown in photo)
[UPH-01-003] Same part with two integrated Bowden clamps.
[UPH-010-010] Required tapered nut for two threaded clamps. I am currently working with a non-standard hot-end design and have not been able to test these designs during actual prints, but the parts fit together well and the Bowden tube feels very secure when I pull on it.

Part UPH-01-001 would can be sliced @ 0.2 mm.  
All threaded parts should be sliced at 0.1 mm with 0.8 mm wall.  30% fill should be enough - but not yet verified.  
It is important to wrap the threads with PTFE tape (used to seal pipe threads, available at hardware stores).  Without the PTFE tape, the threads could be ruined.  One or two wraps of PTFE tape is sufficient.  
Masking tape wrapped around the Bowden tube helps the barbs on the inside diameter of the male thread grip the Bowden tube.  Without the tape, the tube will slide out. 1 1/4 to 1 1/2 wraps of tape is sufficient.

author: P4LIL

description.text:
WARNING: THIS "PROBE" IS A CONCEPT!! It has been printed but not tested in a working environment. .After carefully considering all possible scenarios of end-stop and probes solutions I settled my struggle with the opto-probes for the high end (infrared, laser, etc) and mechanical, direct nozzle-bed contact probes for the low end of the price spectrum. This Thing is to present my current design for a mechanical probe that:
  • doesn't need repetability tests as the design itself doesn't allow errors in this area
  • doesn't need precise positioning relative to the nozzle so it can have various distances to the nozzle each time with the same outcome
  • can be used with heated nozzle on plastic beds (PEI, etc)
  • can be used with any kind of bed (plastic, wood, glass, metal), because it doesn't depend on the bed material and it doesn't damage the bed material
  • is independent of the print head and can be "clamped" to the print head via a G0 G-code command
    • These are many advantages one wants to have but seemingly few people appreciate simple, common-sense solutions these days, where everything must be high tech. Well, it doesn't, and this low-tech solution can be replicated at home when something breaks. It is a design so far, I haven't tested it on a functioning machine but the logic behind it is valid and I've submitted my idea and my design on reprap forums for discussion and scrutiny with positive results so far. It assumes a connection on the hotend (ground most likely) and the 5V connection on the screw on the probe so when nozzle and the metal strip make contact, it triggers the Z_Min on the Arduino. I have attached both STL and RSDOC. RepRap Forums Discussion here: http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?1,620626

Life Lesson:
Our cats love to get up in front of the TV.  I started throwing stuffed animals at them to get them to move.  Our first daughter was 2 at the time and witnessed my "solution".  However she decided that the hard toy would be acceptable, and as a result the 3 week old TV at the time developed a star shaped crack.  That was a life lesson.  Fast forward 4 years and daughter 2 is bouncing around.  And on her own threw a toy at the cat and cracked the TV too.  Now the TV has two stars.  I am sad.   We tried the sticky tape and it was a mess.  Out of desperation, I modified the scad file I found to create the Spikey Cat Deterrent 3000.   It works a champ.  No more cats in front of the TV.
If I would have had a 3D printer, and printed one of these years ago there is a good possibility that my TV wouldn't be cracked :(

title: Hitachi Projector Filter Housing (CPX-200,205,206)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A replacement projector filter housing for the Hitachi CPX-200, CPX-205, and CPX-206. Each of these projectors has a slightly different main filter housing and retaining piece. This design is capable of being used in each and can use each one's retaining piece. The prints that we used for testing are all PLA. We have plans to print with ABS again soon. The corner pads and added support are all that are needed. Filter.stl - This file is the filter housing without optimized support and warp-free material.
Filter-optimized.stl - This file has both the support and anti-warping discs included.

Working on an air assist for the lasersaur. Mine is part of a larger design that incorporates exhaust vents at the lower front of the cutting table. The idea is to suck air out of the lasersaur in the direction away from the laser in order to minimize dust/fumes coating the laser tube or the first 90deg mirror. Update! Video of it in action: http://www.flickr.com/photos/allartburns/6338285065/

This is very much a work in progress, I'll update with instructions when I'm done.
Printing the manifold without support is working fine on my cupcake w/ mk7 stepstruder.  Just make sure the four legs are pointing up.   If you look at the STL you'll see that the box is hollow but that there are three columns holding the top and bottom together.

title: Raspberry Pi Touchscreen Stand with Gap

description.text:
I don't like the dangling power wires blocking the expansion header. There is a USB-A port on the touchscreen board that I want to use to provide power to the Pi, but the stand blocks access to the port.
So I openscad'd a gap in the stand which allows me to put a small USB cable to power the Pi from the Touchscreen logic board.

author: mkellner

title: Tray for holding the screws from a laptop

description.text: I designed this so that as I take a laptop apart I can not only keep the screws in one place and not loose any, but can also have a general idea as to where they came from (so that hopefully I don't end up with a few of those "I'm sure it doesn't need this screw put back in"). It is broken into 4 sections, Screen, keyboard, base and inside and each section has 12 troughs for containing screws in their related spots on the laptop.

author: nanagoochi

description.text:
Center Marking Tool for woodworking.
Created in Tinkercad and printed on DaVinci Jr. Designed to fit 7.5mm diameter pencil. I used one from Home Depot. This tool is very handy and makes it quick and easy to mark a centerline on a board. It will fit over many size boards including the wider part of a 2x4. The pencil fits tight so it holds in place while you drag it across the board. See more detail here:

A tool to convert PNG images into 3D models. It currently exports models in STL and OpenSCAD formats and has a variety of parameters to control the output. It has several http://kyllikki.github.com/png23d/examples.html examples and good http://kyllikki.github.com/png23d/ documentation. The Images and files I have provided here are from the tools examples and are just scratching the surface of what can be achieved.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/iHfrxxKAtxB
IDS project

There are 4 small holes inside this design for small round magnets. Holes are in each corner. You must place the magnets in mid print. This design holds a 1.25" telescope eye piece upright. Great for holding eye pieces in the metal tray built into a number of telescope stands. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/jcGINAxR8ye

Finalized Parts! Feel free to download, as these won't be changing anymore. CowTech Ciclop, designed from the BQ Ciclop, but redesigned to use half the print time, 2/3 of the filament, and a tiny print bed area of only 115mm x 110mm x 65mm (4.5 x 4.3 x 2.6in) so the parts can be printed on nearly any printer. Funded on Kickstarter, raising $183,800 from 1400 backers. Kits now available for pre-order at www.cowtechengineering.com You will need two each of the laser core, laser holder, and pattern holder.
PLA or ABS are both fine. Laser Cut Parts. All sizes in inches.
1x Top T .220
1x Bottom T .220
1x Faceplate .220
1x Turntable .220/.236
1x Frosted .062/.125 (if you don't have frosted acrylic, lightly raster the surface)
1x Pattern .062
3x Wire Holder .220
2x Laser Arm .220 Some of the previews look funky, but they donwload accurately.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes: Camera Base : Support everywhere, no platform adhesion needed Motor base : Support everywhere, no platform adhesion needed Camera Holder: No support, no platform adhesion. Backplate : Support everywhere, no platform adhesion needed (print standing up with flat side down). Laser Holder : Support everywhere, no platform adhesion needed Bearing Holder : No Support, no platform adhesion Laser Holder Core : No Support, brim or raft suggested Gear : No Support needed, brim or raft suggested Note: Orientations do not necessarily match suggested printing orientation.

comments.text: We use 10% support on the two bases, .3mm z gap, 4mm xy spacing. The other parts are a little trickier, but orientation is important on the  back cover, have it facing with the inside of the part towards you, 2mm xy spacing. Laser holders don't really need it, unless you use Cura where the support is a little more controllable. Then we use concentric support pattern and it's great.

description.text:
A simle tool to split aircooled Volkswagen engine cases.
You will need a 3/8 bolt nut and washer. The bolt length is about 1 3/4" long. Trim down a 2" bolt a hair to get the maximum separation. 
Place in the oil pump recess of your engine case and tourqe the nut unitll the case is split. Easy as that. 
EDIT: I added a second file of the same model with an extended bolt hole for little more pushing distance.

title: Thing O Matic corner support feet

description.text:
These are simple supports for the four corners of a TOM. They are the same height as the rubber feet, so they can be used either with or without the rubber feet attached. If you are using any of the printable feet designed to raise up you TOM, these supports will provide a more stable platform, prevent bowing of the bottom piece, and make it possible to move the upper part of the TOM around a bit without having to worry about the printed feet sliding off the bottom plate. Here are the feet you might want to use: Large feet by deltagear: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11414
Small feet by fillibar: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11812
Risers, by me: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13039

There is only a single Sketchup file for the two STL files. This is because you need to print a mirror image of the sketchup file to allow for the tabs on the left front and left back of the TOM. So you need to print four of these supports, with at least one of each type.
Once printed, just slide them under the corners of your Thing-O-Matic and enjoy the greater sense of stability:)

I have tried PLA and you are right, they are solid like a rock, but just be aware they will be more brittle and might not handle hard crashes that well (I'm the crasher kind). So far I've found a great compromise between strength and flexibility in PETG. Have you ever experimented with it?

remixed_from.title: Di3 LCD Angler with E-Stop and SD Slot

description.text:
After printing the Minion case for Ramps for the Mostly Printed CNC, I found that the SD card slot was too far inside the box to easily insert and remove the card (at least for the large graphics LCD panel version).  So I designed a simple "SD Extender" that you can insert your SD card into, and then use it to push into the case.  Since then, I've found this really useful because it gives a nice handle to hold, is easier to pick up off a table, and makes it easier to find the SD card on a table of junk! 
You will find that inserting the SD card is a bit challenging - it will require some effort and finesse to get it into place.  This is intentional, as you will see from the little "bump" I added to help add friction.  This way the card is solidly inserted and won't fall out.  Also note the slot for micro-SD card removal (see pictures) - you can still insert/remove the micro-SD card inside a larger SD card holder, if that is the solution you are using.
You will need to use supports to print this, but they should only be built for the short edges on the end.  Infill can be light as this doesn't need to be strong, and no need for a raft.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

20%

Moving off campus from college, I found myself biking 5 miles round trip, 5 days a week. Living in the northeast U.S I quickly became accustomed to riding in rain,sleet, and snow. This fender was designed to fit a Fuji Monterey 2.0 but will likely work on other models. Fair warning, the larger piece is ~13.5 inches tall so this print is best saved for the larger printers.
